2020-07-17 Riddler Express
==========================
Just noting that a batter who goes 4 for 4 for the first 4 at-bats is
somewhat more likely to get a 5th at-bat, particularly near the top of
the lineup, which is where a .350 hitter would be, and a batter who
goes 0 for 3 in the first 3 at-bats has a small chance of not getting
a 4th at-bat, particularly at the bottom of the lineup.  But, for the
purposes of this puzzle, there are exactly 4 at-bats in each game.

For a 60 game season, there are 240 at-bats.  That means at least 96
hits to bat at least .400.

For a 162 game season, there are 648 at-bats.  That means at least 260
hits to bat at least .400.

Let _b = .350_ be the batting average and _N_ be the total at-bats.

The chance of getting exactly _n_ hits is
_C(N,n)b<sup>n</sup>(1-b)<sup>N-n</sup>_.

Using [code](20200717x.hs) to sum from _n_ from _.4N_ to _N_ gives

for 240 at-bats: 
or approximately: 6.08%

for 648 at-bats: 
or approximately: 0.379%

The chance of going 0 for 4 is 28561/160000 or about 17.85%, so the chance of
getting a hit in any particular game is 131439/160000 or about 82.15%.

Let _h = 131439/160000_ be the chance of getting a hit in a game.

The chance of an _n_ game hitting streak in _n_ games is _h<sup>n</sup>_.

The chance of an _n_ game hitting streak in _n+m_ games is
_s<sub>n,m</sub> = h<sup>n</sup> + (1-h<sup>n</sup>)s<sub>n,m-1</sub>_, where
_s<sub>n,m</sub> = 0_ when _m < 0_.

Using [code](20200717x.hs) to calculate

For 60 games: 
or approximately 0.1007%.

For 162 games: 
or approximately 0.2688%

I don't know a good way to calculate the chances of hitting .400 and having
a 56 game hitting streak in a 60 game season.  A brute force calculation would
be to enumerate all the combinations of hits and outs adding up to 240 at-bats,
that have at last 96 hits, eliminate all that don't have a 56 game hitting
streak, i.e. precluded by at least one or two 0-4 games, calculating the
chance of each remaining combination, then adding them all up for the answer.
